content.question: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. A particle, <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, is moving along the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis. The velocity of particle <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="v sub P, of t, equals, the sine of, open parenthesis, t raised to the 1.5 power, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1.5</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="2.4ex" width="0.0em"></mspace><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to pi" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, particle <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is at position <math alttext="x equals 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. A second particle, <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, also moves along the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis. The velocity of particle <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="v sub Q, of t, equals, open parenthesis, t minus 1.8, close parenthesis, times 1.25 to the t power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1.8</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.15em"></mspace><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo largeop="true">⋅</mo></mrow></mstyle><msup><mrow><mn>1.25</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to pi" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, particle <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is at position <math alttext="x equals 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find the positions of particles <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at time <math alttext="t equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. A particle, <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, is moving along the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis. The velocity of particle <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="v sub P, of t, equals, the sine of, open parenthesis, t raised to the 1.5 power, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1.5</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="2.4ex" width="0.0em"></mspace><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to pi" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, particle <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is at position <math alttext="x equals 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. A second particle, <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, also moves along the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis. The velocity of particle <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="v sub Q, of t, equals, open parenthesis, t minus 1.8, close parenthesis, times 1.25 to the t power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1.8</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.15em"></mspace><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mo largeop="true">⋅</mo></mrow></mstyle><msup><mrow><mn>1.25</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to pi" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, particle <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is at position <math alttext="x equals 10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find the positions of particles <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at time <math alttext="t equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Are particles <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> moving toward each other or away from each other at time <math alttext="t equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Explain your reasoning.

(c) Find the acceleration of particle <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at time <math alttext="t equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is the speed of particle <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> increasing or decreasing at time <math alttext="t equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Explain your reasoning.

(d) Find the total distance traveled by particle <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the time interval <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to pi" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 4.2: Straight-Line Motion - Connecting Position, Velocity, and Acceleration

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
